questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a leading cause of mortality in children aged 1-4 years in developing countries?

options.A: Diarrhoeal diseases
options.B: Respiratory infections
options.C: Malnutrition
options.D: Congenital anomalies

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Congenital Anomalies Explanation: Congenital anomalies are a cause of mortality in age 1-4 years, they are not among the leading causes in developing countries. They are more prevalent as leading causes of mortality in developed countries. Causes of mortality in age group 1-4 years: Developing Countries Developed Countries Diarrhoeal diseases Accidents and injuries Respiratory infections Congenital anomalies Malnutrition Malignant neoplasms Infectious diseases (e.g., measles, whooping cough) Influenza Other febrile diseases Pneumonia

questions.question: Under which initiative in India are children screened for common health conditions such as birth defects, deficiencies, developmental delays, and diseases up to the age of 18 years?

options.A: Anemia Mukt Bharat
options.B: Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)
options.C: Applied Nutrition Programme
options.D: Mid-day Meal

questions.explanation: Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an initiative promoting school health Comprehensive health care for children aged from birth to 18 years by screening them for birth defects, diseases, deficiencies, and developmental delays. Children identified with these conditions receive early intervention and follow-up care provided free of cost including surgeries. Other initiatives promoting school health: Anemia Mukt Bharat (Option 1) - Providing iron and folic acid supplements - under WIFS (Weekly Iron Folic Acid Supplementation) 5-9 year children: Weekly 1 IFA - 45 mg. of Fe + 400 mcg. of folic acid, sugar-coated - pink color. Biannual deworming with one tablet of Albendazole tablet 400 mg done during the National Deworming days once in 6 months (10 of Aug and 10 of Feb of every year) Adolescent boys and girls - weekly 1 IFA - containing 100 mg Fe and 500 mcg of folic acid and biannual deworming with 1 tablet of 400 mg Albendazole. Menstrual hygiene management: Sanitary pads are provided to girls Usually in rural areas Nutritional Services: PM POSHAN (POshan SHAkti Nirman) Scheme Previously called as National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools ( Mid-Day Meal Scheme ) (Option 4) Provides one hot cooked meal ( I Calories, ½ protein) to school children studying in Classes I-VIII in Government and Government-aided schools. To prevent dropouts. MID DAY MEAL PROGRAM Applied Nutrition Programme (Option 3): In collaboration with UNICEF- Provides and implements seeds, manure, and water supply equipment to develop school gardens.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding a healthful school environment? students. and girls. primary schools, with an additional 1 acre per 100 students.

options.A: Classrooms should accommodate no more than 40 students with a minimum of 10 sq. ft. per student.
options.B: The interior walls of classrooms should be colorfully painted to create a stimulating environment for
options.C: One urinal per 60 students, one latrine per 100 students must be provided. Separate facilities for boys
options.D: Site should be on high-lying land with an area of 10 acres for higher elementary schools, 5 acres for

questions.explanation: stimulating environment for students. stimulating environment for students Explanation: The interior walls of classrooms should be white-washed , not colorfully painted. White walls help in maintaining cleanliness and provide a calm environment in the classroom. Healthful School Environment Aspect Details Location Centrally situated with proper approach roads, away from busy places like roads, factories, and marketplaces. School premises should be fenced and hazard-free. Site High, well-drained land. 10 acres for higher elementary schools, 5 acres for primary schools, with an additional 1 acre per 100 students. (Option 4) Structure Single-story buildings are preferred. Exterior walls should be 10 inches thick and heat-resistant Classroom No more than 40 students per room. Minimum 10 sq. ft. per student. (Option 1) Color of Interior White interior walls, periodically white-washed. Lighting Natural light from the left side, not from the front. Water Supply Independent source of safe, potable water, continuous supply distributed from taps. Lavatory One urinal per 60 students, one latrine per 100 students. Separate facilities for boys and girls. (Option 3) Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition. Pg. 658

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is incorrect? frequent breastfeeding.

options.A: KMC involves early and prolonged skin-to-skin contact between the infant and the mother.
options.B: KMC is meant for clinically stable low birth weight (LBW) infants and includes exclusive and
options.C: KMC should only be provided in hospitals under skilled supervision and proper guidance.
options.D: KMC helps stabilize body temperature, promotes breastfeeding, and prevents infections.

questions.explanation: guidance. guidance. Explanation: KMC should be initiated in the hospital under skilled supervision but is intended to be continued at home to provide ongoing benefits to the infant. Kangaroo Mother Care is a low-resource, high-impact intervention for low birth weight infants. It has the following benefits:- (Option 4) Stabilizing the infant's body temperature and preventing hypothermia Reducing neonatal mortality and risk of infections Promoting effective breastfeeding Reducing the length of hospital stay Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) has 4 main components:- Kangaroo Position- Prolonged skin-to-skin contact (Option 1) Kangaroo Nutrition- Exclusive and frequent breastfeeding (Option 2) Kangaroo Discharge- The infant is sent home early, as soon as the mother can provide all basic care. Kangaroo support- Close follow-up and access to daily visits. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 615 National Health Mission- Guidelines for KMC

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding artificial feeding in infants? to about 1.5 g/kg by the end of one year. animal, or commercial formulae mother.

options.A: The estimated protein requirement is about 2 g/kg of body weight during the first 6 months; Declines
options.B: Options used in artificial feeding include dried whole milk powder, fresh milk from a cow or other
options.C: Cow milk is the safest and most commonly used artificial feeding method in developing countries
options.D: The main indications for artificial feeding are failure of breast milk, prolonged illness or death of the

questions.explanation: developing countries developing countries. Explanation: While cow milk is a commonly used alternative for infant feeding in developing countries due to its availability and cost, it is not considered the safest option . Cow milk contains higher levels of bacteria than dried milk powder It requires dilution to reduce the solute load on neonatal kidneys It lacks certain essential nutrients that are present in breast milk or commercial formulae, which are specifically designed to meet the nutritional needs of infants. Artificial Feeding Options (Option 2) Dried Whole Milk Powder Fresh Milk from a Cow or Other Animal Commercial Formulae Donor Human Milk Nutritional Requirements and Feeding Guidelines for Infants Requirement/Guideline Details Energy Requirement Infants require an average of 100 kcal per kg of body weight per day (about 150 ml of milk per kg of body weight each day). Protein Requirement 2 g/kg of body weight during the first 6 months. Declines to about 1.5 g/kg by the end of one year. (Option 1) Feeding Frequency Infants need feeding at frequent intervals about 6-8 times a day. Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition. Pg. 615-616.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect when comparing human milk to cow milk? essential for infants. undigested. more Vitamin A and C neonatal kidneys.

options.A: Human milk contains 3 times lower protein, but is rich in amino acids like cysteine and taurine,
options.B: Breast milk is almost completely digested, whereas much of cow's milk protein is excreted
options.C: The coefficient of uptake of iron is equal in both breast and cow milk, however breast milk contains
options.D: Dilution of cow's milk during the first 2 months is recommended in order to reduce the solute load on

questions.explanation: breast milk contains more Vitamin A and C breast milk contains more Vitamin A and C. Explanation : This statement is incorrect. The coefficient of uptake of iron is not equal in both breast and cow milk. Human milk has a higher bioavailability of iron compared to cow milk. Additionally, human milk does contain more Vitamin A and C compared to cow milk. Nutritional Component Human Milk Cow Milk Protein Content Lower, easily digestible (Option 1) Higher, harder to digest Essential Amino Acids (e.g., cysteine, taurine) Rich Lower Vitamin A & C Rich Lower Iron Higher bioavailability Lower bioavailability Calcium Adequate, better absorbed Higher content, less effectively absorbed Fat Content Higher proportion of essential fatty acids (e.g., linoleic, alpha-linolenic) Lower proportion of essential fatty acids Digestibility Almost completely digested Much is excreted undigested (Option 2) Risk of Overloading Kidneys Low High (hence dilution recommended) (Option 4) Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition. Pg. 616

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of poor dietary intake for the past several months. On examination, the child has Bitot's spots and other signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the most appropriate treatment plan for this child to correct the Vitamin A deficiency? after 9 months. turns 5 years. third dose of 200,000 IU 2-4 weeks later.

options.A: Administer a single dose of 50,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and repeat the dose the next day.
options.B: Administer a single dose of 100,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and another dose of 100,000 IU
options.C: Administer 50,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and repeat this dose every 6 months until the child
options.D: Administer 200,000 IU of vitamin A immediately and the very next day. If clinical signs persist,

questions.explanation: clinical signs persist, third dose of 200,000 IU 2-4 weeks later. clinical signs persist, give a third dose of 200,000 IU 2-4 weeks later. Explanation: Immediate High Dose: The initial high dose of 200,000 IU is necessary to rapidly replenish vitamin A levels in the body, addressing the acute deficiency and preventing further deterioration. Follow-Up Dose: Repeating the dose the next day ensures that the body receives a sufficient amount of vitamin A to start correcting the deficiency effectively. 2 Doses are mostly sufficient to reverse the ocular signs of Vitamin A deficiency. Third Dose if Needed: A third dose after 2-4 weeks may be required if clinical signs persist, ensuring that the deficiency is fully corrected. Dose Schedule for Management of Vitamin A Deficiency Age Range Vitamin A Dose Frequency < 6 months 50,000 IU 1st Dose - Day 0 2nd Dose- Day 1 3rd Dose (if required) - 2-4 weeks later 6-11 months 100,000 IU 1st Dose - Day 0 2nd Dose- Day 1 3rd Dose (if required) - 2-4 weeks later ≥ 12 months 200,000 IU 1st Dose - Day 0 2nd Dose- Day 1 3rd Dose (if required) - 2-4 weeks later Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 166, 731

questions.question: A 2-year-old child presents with bilateral pedal edema, severe wasting, and a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of 10.5 cm. Which of the following is the feature of initial management of this condition?

options.A: Focus on nutritional and electrolyte balance
options.B: Starter Diet provides 100 kcal per 1000 ml
options.C: Initiation of a home-based nutritious diet
options.D: Provide a catch up diet like F-100

questions.explanation: described in the question, including bilateral pedal edema , severe wasting , and a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of 10.5 cm , are suggestive of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) The clinical features described in the question, including bilateral pedal edema , severe wasting , and a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of 10.5 cm , are suggestive of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) The first step in the treatment of SAM, particularly in an inpatient setting, involves correcting electrolyte imbalances (such as low potassium or sodium), rehydration, and replenishing micronutrient deficiencies before initiating feeding.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding growth charts is false?

options.A: The position of dots is more important than direction
options.B: Flattening of the curve is a sign of growth failure
options.C: 0 to -2 SD signifies normal growth
options.D: 50th percentile is the upper reference for boys in the WHO growth chart

questions.explanation: of the curve is more important than the position of the dots as it focuses on the trajectory of a child's growth over time, and helps identify if a child is growing steadily, experiencing rapid growth, or potentially showing signs of growth faltering. Features of ICDS growth chart : CRITERIA FOR ICDS GROWTH CHART 0 to -2 SD Road to health Green color Advice : Take care of danger signs. -2 to -3 SD Mild to moderate malnutrition Yellow color Advice : Supplement with diet and breastfeeding. Below -3 SD Severe malnutrition Red color Refer to a CHC level or above FEATURES OF ICDS GROWTH CHART Has 3 lines Weight is on the y-axis Age is on the x-axis The first sign of growth failure is the flattening of the curve. The direction of the growth chart is more important than the position of the dots. Features of WHO GROWTH CHART : Upper reference (50th percentile for boys) Lower reference (3rd percentile for girls) Between the two references - Normal growth Below lower reference - Malnutrition

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of a severe acute malnourished child?

options.A: MUAC < 11.5 cm
options.B: Low weight for height < -3 SD
options.C: Absence of pitting pedal edema
options.D: Presence of severe body wasting

questions.explanation: pedal edema is an important feature of severe acute malnourished child Criteria Details Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) Less than 11.5 cm (Option 1) Weight-for-height Less than -3 SD (standard deviations) on the WHO growth chart. (Option 2) Bilateral pitting pedal edema Presence of edema, which is swelling caused by fluid retention, in both feet. Visible severe wasting Noticeable and significant loss of body mass, particularly muscle and fat tissue. (Option 4) SAM children meeting these criteria are to be admitted to Nutritional Rehabilitation Centres (NRCs) for treatment and care. Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 26th Edition page 730

questions.question: The image above depicts a measurement used to assess the nutritional status of children. What is being measured?

options.A: Head circumference
options.B: Mid upper arm circumference
options.C: Abdominal girth
options.D: Leg length

questions.explanation: arm circumference (MUAC), which is the most sensitive indicator for assessment of malnutrition status. COLOUR Measurement Status RED < 11.5 cm Severe acute malnutrition YELLOW 11.5-12.5 cm Undernourished GREEN >12.5 cm Normal Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8183198/ https://www.unicef.org/supply/media/1421/file /mid-upper-arm-circumference-measuring-tapes-technical-bulletin.pdf

questions.question: In a pediatric clinic, a 4-year-old child is assessed using Waterlow's Classification. The child's height-for-age is found to be 85%, while weight-for-height is 85%. According to Waterlow's Classification, the nutritional status of this child would be categorized as:

options.A: Normal
options.B: Wasted
options.C: Stunted
options.D: Wasted and Stunted

questions.explanation: ≥ 80% and Height for Age < 90% is termed as Stunted. Weight for Heigh t Height for Age Nutritional Status ≥ 80% ≥ 90% Normal < 80% ≥ 90% Wasted ≥ 80% < 90% Stunted < 80% < 90% Wasted and Stunted Other classifications of malnutrition include the Gomez classification and the Wellcome Trust classification. Reference: https://doi.org/10.37506/ijphrd.v11i7.10047 .

questions.question: Non-clinical Question: Match the following markers to the type of malnutrition they best assess:- Marker Type of Malnutrition a. Weight-for-height 1. Chronic Malnutrition b. Height-for-age 2. Acute Malnutrition C. Weight-for-age 3. Acute on chronic malnutrition
questions.explanation: (wasting). Height-for-age assesses chronic malnutrition (stunting). Weight-for-age is an overall indicator but does not differentiate between acute and chronic malnutrition, making it less specific for either. Head circumference is a general indicator that can reflect both acute and chronic malnutrition, but it's not the primary marker for either. Reference: K. Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition- Pg. 686

questions.question: What is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended by the WHO?
questions.explanation: (or Antenatal care contact) is 8. Schedule of visits: 1st Trimester: 1 visit ( in the first 12 weeks) 2nd Trimester: 2 visits ( at 20 & 26 weeks) 3rd Trimester: 5 visits ( at 30, 34, 36, 38 and 40 weeks) It is recommends that pregnant women have their first contact in the first 12 weeks of gestation, with subsequent contacts taking place at 20, 26, 30, 34, 36, 38, and 40 weeks’ gestation. The minimum number of visits per MOHFW is 4. Reference: WHO guidelines on ANC visits

questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE with respect to mortality rates in children? UNICEF.

options.A: The most common cause of neonatal mortality is low birth weight.
options.B: Sepsis is a significant cause of both neonatal and infant mortality.
options.C: The Infant Mortality Rate is considered the best indicator of socio-economic development by
options.D: Current IMR is 28/1000 live births.

questions.explanation: development by UNICEF. development by UNICEF. Explanation: UNICEF considers the Under-5 Mortality Rate , not the Infant Mortality Rate, as the single best indicator of overall socio-economic development and well-being of society. Low birth weight/ prematurity is recognized as the most common cause of neonatal mortality, infant mortality as well as Under-5 Mortality Rate . Sepsis is a significant cause of mortality in both neonates and infants. The current Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) in India is 28 per 1000 live births as given by the sample registration system. Reference: K. Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition- Pg. 641 to 651.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman gives birth to a baby at 36 weeks of gestation. The baby's birth weight is recorded as 1800 grams. The mother is concerned about the baby's health and asks the pediatrician about the potential risks and necessary care for her newborn. Given the clinical scenario, which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the newborn? 1) The baby is classified as moderately preterm and moderately low birth weight. 2) The baby is classified as extremely preterm and extremely low birth weight. 3) The baby is at a higher risk for infant mortality compared to normal birth weight babies. 4) The baby is expected to double its birth weight by 3 months. 5) The baby is classified as normal term and moderately low birth weight.

options.A: 1 and 3
options.C: 3 and 5

questions.explanation: moderately preterm , & according to birth weight is a moderately LBW baby. Classification Weight Range Moderately Low Birth Weight 1500 g to 2499 g Very Low Birth Weight 1000 g to 1499 g Extremely Low Birth Weight Below 1000 g Classification Gestational Age Extremely Preterm Less than 28 weeks Very Preterm 28 to 32 weeks Moderate to Late Preterm 32 to 37 weeks Term 37 to 42 weeks Post-term Beyond 42 weeks Also, birth weight doubles by 5 months, triples by 1 year, and quadruples by 2 years . Infant Mortality rate is 20 times higher in LBW babies. In fact, LBW is the single most important factor influencing child survival. Reference: K. Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition- Pg. 641 to 649.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Perinatal Mortality Rate (PMR) is FALSE? days of life.

options.A: PMR includes late fetal deaths from 28 weeks of gestation and early neonatal deaths within the first 7
options.B: PMR is considered the best indicator for combined obstetrics and pediatrics care.
options.C: The weight of the fetus should be at least 2 kg to be included in the PMR.
options.D: Birth asphyxia is a significant cause of perinatal mortality.

questions.explanation: the PMR. Criteria for PMR: 28 weeks of gestation The weight of the fetus should be at least 1 kg Length of fetus at least 35 cm Perinatal mortality rate = [Late fetal death (28 weeks of gestation) + early neonatal death (0 -7 days)] / live births x 1000 (Option 1). PMR is the best indicator for combined obstetrics and pediatrics care , as it considers both. (Option 2) Birth Asphyxia is a significant cause of Perinatal mortality. (Option 4) Reference: K. Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition- Pg. 641 to 649 Child Health

questions.question: What is the current Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) in India according to the Sample Registration System (SRS)?

options.A: 30 per 1000 live births
options.B: 28 per 1000 live births
options.C: 25 per 1000 live births
options.D: 20 per 1000 live births

questions.explanation: (IMR) is 28 per 1000 live births, as reported by the Sample Registration System (SRS). Infant mortality rate (IMR) is expressed as the number of deaths of infants (aged 0-1 year) per 1000 live births in a given year. Infant mortality rate (IMR) = (No. of deaths of children (infant) 0-1 year of life / live births) x 1000) Causes: The most common cause is low birth weight/prematurity according to the latest update Other causes include asphyxia, ARIs, diarrhea, congenital anomalies, cord infection, birth trauma, and others. Most infant deaths occur within the first month of life, with a significant proportion (54.6%) occurring during the first week. The risk of death is highest within the first 24-48 hours after birth. IMR reflects the effectiveness of maternal and child health (MCH) services and overall healthcare infrastructure in preventing infant deaths. Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition. Pg. 646 Child Health

questions.question: Which of the following defines the Neonatal Mortality Rate?

options.A: Death of a child within 0-28 days of life per 1000 live births
options.B: Death of a child within 0-7 days of life per 1000 live births
options.C: Death of a child within 8-28 days of life per 1000 live births
options.D: Death of a child within 29 days to 1 year of life per 1000 live births

questions.explanation: Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) measures the number of deaths of infants within the first 28 days of life per 1000 live births. It is calculated as, Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) = (No. of deaths of children (neonates) 0 – 28 days of life / live births) x 1000 Causes of Neonatal deaths: Most common cause: low birth weight/ prematurity Other causes : Birth asphyxia/hypoxia Neonatal pneumonia Sepsis Congenital anomalies Diarrhea Injuries Other non-communicable diseases Danger Signs: Refusal to feed Lethargy Cold to touch Difficult or rapid breathing Convulsions Persistent vomiting Jaundice at birth Blue color of extremities Other Neonatal Mortality Indicators: Early neonatal mortality rate (Option 2) (No. of deaths of children (neonate) 0 – 7 days of life / live births) x 1000) Late neonatal mortality rate (Option 3) (No. of deaths of children (neonate) 8th – 28 days of life / live birth) x 1000) Post-neonatal mortality rate (Option 4) (No. of deaths of children (neonate) 29th day - 1 year of life / live births) x 1000) Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition. Pg. 643

questions.question: A state recorded 150 maternal deaths in a year. The number of live births during the same period was 50,000. The total number of women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is 10,00,000. What is the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for this state?

options.A: 3.0 per 1,000 women of reproductive age
options.B: 1.5 per 1,000 live births
options.C: 300 per 100,000 live births
options.D: 15 per 100,000 women of reproductive age

questions.explanation: maternal mortality ratio. Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is the number of maternal deaths during the antenatal period, during delivery, and up to 42 days post delivery per 100,000 live births. It is calculated as follows: Maternal Mortality Ratio = ( No. of maternal deaths / No. of Live births ) x 100000 So the answer will be, (150/50000) x 100000 = 300 (option 3) Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) is the number of maternal deaths during the antenatal period, during delivery, and up to 42 days post-delivery per 1,00,000 women of reproductive age (aged 15-49 years) in a given period. It is calculated as follows: Maternal Mortality Rate = (Number of maternal deaths / No. of women in reproductive age group) x 100000 MM Rate with the given data will be MM Rate = (150/1000000)x100000= 15 (Option 4) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 635

questions.question: What is the minimum number of postnatal visits by ASHA workers recommended in the case of a home delivery?

options.A: 4 visits on Day 3, Day 7, Day 14, and Day 42
options.B: 4 visits on Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, and Day 42
options.C: 6 visits on Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, Day 14, Day 21, and Day 42
options.D: 7 visits on Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, Day 14, Day 21, Day 28, and Day 42

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 7 visits on Day 1, Day 3, Day 7, Day 14, Day 21, Day 28, and Day 42 delivery. They make several visits to ensure proper postnatal care, with the number of visits varying depending on whether the delivery takes place, at home or in an institution. Guidelines for home visits by ANM and ASHA workers: Postnatal Care by ANM HBNC by ASHA Home Delivery Minimum 4 visits on Day 1,3,7 and 42 Minimum 7 visits on Day 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42 Institutional Delivery Minimum 3 visits on Day 3, 7 and 42 Minimum 6 visits on Day 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, 42 In the case of Caesarean section delivery, Day 3 is spent in the hospital and the minimum number of visits by ANM is 2 and ASHA is 5. ASHA is paid 250 rupees per child after the completion of scheduled home visits. Reference: HBNC & HBYC :: National Health Mission

questions.question: Which maternal health initiative launched by the National Health Mission focuses on improving the quality of care in labor rooms and maternity operation theaters?

options.A: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA)
options.B: Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)
options.C: Dakshata Training
options.D: LaQshya

questions.explanation: on decreasing preventable maternal and newborn deaths, illnesses, and stillbirths by enhancing the quality of care during labor and delivery and ensuring respectful maternity care. Objectives include: Managing complications like APH, PPH, preterm labor, and sepsis Improving care during delivery and the postpartum period Ensuring prompt referrals Promoting patient satisfaction and respectful treatment for all pregnant women in public health facilities Other Maternal Health Initiatives: Initiative Aims Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA) (Option 1) To offer free, comprehensive, and high-quality antenatal care to all pregnant women on the 9th of each month. Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) Entitles all pregnant women giving birth in public health institutions to receive completely free services, including cesarean sections, and also covers free transportation. Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) (Option 2) To reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional deliveries among poor pregnant women through financial incentives. SUMAN - Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan Free, respectful healthcare with zero service denials, aiming to prevent maternal and newborn deaths. Beneficiaries include all pregnant women, up to 6 months post-delivery, and sick infants. Dakshata Training (Option 3) A training program designed to enhance the skills and competencies of healthcare providers in intrapartum and immediate postpartum care.

questions.question: A 28 y/o pregnant woman, currently at 24 weeks of gestation, visits you for her routine antenatal check-up. She reports feeling excessive thirst and has been urinating more frequently than usual. She also mentions occasional fatigue. Her obstetric history includes a previous pregnancy with a baby weighing 4.2 kg at birth. Which of the following tests would you recommend for her?

options.A: Random Blood Sugar Test (RBS)
options.B: Fasting Blood Sugar Test (FBS)
options.C: Oral glucose challenge test (OGCT)
options.D: HbA1c Test

questions.explanation: trimester and has complaints of polydipsia and polyuria . She also has a history of giving birth to an overweight baby ( Macrosomia ). This suggests the possibility of her having Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM). The OGCT is commonly used as a screening test for GDM. Procedure: The patient is given a 50g oral glucose solution to drink. One hour after drinking the glucose solution, blood is drawn to measure blood glucose levels. Interpretation: A 140 mg/dL or higher blood glucose level is considered abnormal and warrants further testing with an OGTT. The OGTT (Oral Glucose Tolerance Test) is a diagnostic test for GDM. OGTT is performed in the 1st antenatal visit and then repeated again at 24-28 weeks POG Procedure: A fasting blood sample is drawn to measure the baseline glucose level. The patient drinks a 75g oral glucose solution. Blood samples are drawn one hour and two hours after drinking the glucose solution. Interpretation: According to DIPSI guidelines, the diagnosis of GDM is made if any of the following plasma glucose values are met or exceeded: Fasting: 92 mg/dL 1 hour: 180 mg/dL 2 hours: 153 mg/dL This 2-step approach is widely recommended and provides a reliable method for diagnosing GDM. RBS, FBS, and HbA1c tests ( Options 1 , 2, & 4) are less specific and commonly used for ruling out overt diabetes mellitus and diagnosing GDM. Reference: Screening & diagnosis of GDM- NIH

questions.question: A 25 y/o primigravida, in her 2nd month of pregnancy, has come to you for her routine antenatal checkup. On further questioning, you find out that she has not been given any vaccinations yet. Which of the following is TRUE regarding vaccination protocols in pregnancy?

options.A: A booster dose of the Td vaccine is enough for this patient
options.B: 3 doses of Td vaccine must be given
options.C: 1st Td dose should be given as soon as possible
options.D: 2nd dose should be given 48 days after the 1st dose

questions.explanation: the 1st Td dose should be given as soon as possible. Vaccination protocol in pregnancy: A booster dose of the Td vaccine is not enough for this patient because a booster dose is only given to multigravida mothers with last childbirth within 3 years (Option 1) . Only 2 doses of Td must be given in primigravida (Option 2) . The 2nd dose must be given after 28 days after the 1st dose, not after 48 days (Option 4) . Reference: Vaccination during pregnancy(NIH)

questions.question: A 23 y/o woman, who works at a construction site, comes to you with obstetric code G1P0L0, in her 2nd trimester for her 2nd routine check-up. She is anemic and has a Hb value of 8.4g/dl. Which of the following would not be the right advice for her?

options.A: She should take 1 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablet daily.
options.B: She should increase her calorie intake
options.C: She should increase her calcium and vitamin A intake .
options.D: She must come for at least 2 more ANC visits

questions.explanation: primigravida & also she is anemic. Pregnant women with normal Hb levels (>11 g/dl) must take 1 IFA tablet daily. Whereas, all pregnant women with Hb between 7-9 g/dl must take 2 IFA tablets daily. For mothers with < 7g/dl = injectables are given. She needs to increase her calorie intake (Option 2) as per the nutritional Requirements in Pregnancy: Calorie requirements according to NIN (National Institute of Nutrition) Pregnancy: +350 kcal/day. Lactation: 0-6 months: +600 kcal/day. 7-12 months: +520 kcal/day. Ideal time 1st trimester: No additional calories required. 2nd trimester: 350 kcal/day. 3rd trimester: 450 kcal/day. Daily allowance for females Sedentary: 1660 kcal. Moderate: 2100 kcal. Heavy worker: 2700 kcal. +350 means we add to sedentary (1660). Calcium and vitamin A intake should be increased (Option 3) because the nutrient requirements that increase during pregnancy and lactation are: I Calcium I Vitamin A I Iodine She must come for at least 2 more ANC visits as the minimum number of ANC visits is 4, according to the Government of India (Option 4). First visit : As soon as pregnancy is suspected, or within the first three months of a missed period Second visit : Between 14–26 weeks Third visit : Between 28–36 weeks Fourth visit : Between 36 weeks and term Reference: IFA in pregnancy Antenatal iron supplementation Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page 748 GOI guidelines on ANC
